info.title: National Park Service
info.description: The National Park Service API and developer resources are designed to provide authoritative NPS data and content for internal and external developers creating apps, maps, and websites. You'll find photos and essential information about NPS sites including visitor centers, campgrounds, events, news, alerts, and more, as well as detailed articles about NPS natural and cultural features and important people and places.

get.description: Retrieve categories of activities (astronomy, hiking, wildlife watching, etc.) possible in national parks.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: One or more activity unique IDs.

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Term to search on.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Number of results to return per request. Default is 50.

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: Get the next [limit] results starting with this number. Default is 0.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of fields to sort the results by. Ascending order is assumed for each field unless the field name is prefixed with the unary negative which implies descending order.

get.description: Retrieve events created by national parks and other NPS entities.

parameters.name: parkCode
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of park codes (each 4 characters in length).

parameters.name: organization
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of organization site codes.

parameters.name: subject
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of subject site codes.

parameters.name: portal
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of portal site codes.

parameters.name: tagsAll
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of tags that must be included.

parameters.name: tagsOne
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of tags that may be included.

parameters.name: tagsNone
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of tags that must not be included.

parameters.name: stateCode
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of 2 character state codes.

parameters.name: dateStart
parameters.description: A stating date in the yyyy-mm-dd format to filter events by.

parameters.name: dateEnd
parameters.description: An ending date in the yyyy-mm-dd format to filter events by.

parameters.name: eventType
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of event types.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: A unique ID string for an event.

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Term to search on.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description: The number of results per page. Default is 10.

parameters.name: pageNumber
parameters.description: The current page number for the results. Default is 1.

parameters.name: expandRecurring
parameters.description: A flag to denote whether or not to expand the recurring events out into multiple records (one per event date). Default is false.

get.description: Retrieve lesson plans created by national parks and other NPS entities.

parameters.name: parkCode
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of park codes (each 4 characters in length).

parameters.name: stateCode
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of 2 character state codes.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Number of results to return per request. Default is 50.

parameters.name: start
parameters.description: Get the next [limit] results starting with this number. Default is 0.

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Term to search on.

parameters.name: sort
parameters.description: A comma delimited list of resource properties to sort the results by. Each resource identifies which properties are 'sortable'. Ascending order is assumed for each property. If descending order is desired, the unary negative should prefix the property name. The sortable properties are listed in the documentation for each resource. Invalid property values will be ignored. Default is title.

weatheroverview.title: Weather Overview
weatheroverview.description: General description of the weather in the campground over the course of a year.

accessibility.wheelchairaccess: Some restrooms are wheelchair accessible. The campground is mainly accessed by transit bus, around half of which are wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.firestovepolicy: Open fires are prohibited at Wonder Lake Campground. Bring a camping stove of some kind to cook your meals.
accessibility.adainfo: Paths between campsites vary from compact gravel to muddy, rocky surfaces. The campground is laid out with some sites on a small hill above the level of the main campground road, while others are level with or slightly downhill from the level of the road.
accessibility.rvinfo: This is a tent-only campsite; RVs and trailers are prohibited at Wonder Lake.

example.description: Wonder Lake Campground is at mile 85 on the Denali Park Road. It offers 28 sites, which are all tent-only.  It is the closest campground to Denali. Though separated by nearly 26 miles, the sheer size of the mountain makes it loom impressively over Wonder Lake Campground. Cloudy skies can obscure views, and mosquitoes can be fierce, but Wonder Lake on a clear day offers views that will last a lifetime. Bear-proof food lockers are available throughout the campground.
example.directionsoverview: Visitors may not drive to this campground. It is only accessible for campers via specialized park buses. Be sure to book a camper bus ticket in addition to paying your campground fees.
example.name: Wonder Lake
example.weatheroverview: Wonder Lake tends to be cooler and wetter than the park entrance. Expect lows in the upper 30s or 40s each night. Daytime highs are typically in the upper 50s or 60s, though occasional sunny days can result in temps near 80. Mosquitoes are particularly bad most of the summer - bring a headnet!

accessibility.adainfo: Surfaces in the campground are largely compacted gravel or native soils with roots and rocks. The path from the campground to the bus stop on the Denali Park Road is compacted gravel. Restrooms are wheelchair accessible.

example.description: Igloo Creek Campground is at mile 35 on the Park Road. It offers 7 sites, making it the smallest in Denali (along with Sanctuary River Campground, which also has 7 sites).  Igloo is tent-only - you will not find any RVs or other vehicles in this campground. It is accessible by camper bus. The bus stop is a short walk from the camp sites - less than 50 yards (meters).  Advance reservations are not possible at this campground. Visitors may only book a site upon arriving in the park.
example.directionsoverview: This campground can only be reached by bus. Be sure to book a camper bus ticket when purchasing a stay at Igloo Creek Campground.
example.name: Igloo Creek
example.weatheroverview: We recommend you bring a sleeping bag rated to 20 degrees F. Expect rain, though sunny days do occur periodically throughout the summer. Highs are usually in the 60s, though sometimes can reach the low 80s. Snow is possible any month of the year, however.

example.questionobjective: In "Dawes Act," students will look at the similarities and differences between the Homestead Act and the Dawes Act by analyzing primary sources.  In this lesson, students will answer the following essential question: What are the cause and effects of the Dawes Act?
example.subject: Social Studies
example.title: Dawes Act

example.gradelevel: Upper Elementary: Third Grade through Fifth Grade
example.questionobjective: This program utilizes multimedia, exhibits, oral presentations and the memorial landscape to deliver a unique learning opportunity.  The overall objective of this program is to expose students to the various passengers and crew members of Flight 93: Who they were, their names, what made them unique, and how do we remember them today at the memorial. There will also be a special emphasis on the story of Flight 93 and the actions of the passengers and crew members.
example.subject: Social Studies
example.title: A Walk to Remember

example.description: Visit Yellowstone and experience the world's first national park. Marvel at a volcano's hidden power rising up in colorful hot springs, mudpots, and geysers. Explore mountains, forests, and lakes to watch wildlife and witness the drama of the natural world unfold. Discover the history that led to the conservation of our national treasures 'for the benefit and enjoyment of the people.'
example.directionsInfo: Yellowstone National Park covers nearly 3,500 square miles in the northwest corner of Wyoming (3% of the park is in Montana and 1% is in Idaho). Yellowstone has five entrance stations, and several are closed to regular vehicles during winter. It takes many hours to drive between these entrances, so be sure to check the status of roads at the entrance you intend to use while planning your trip and before you arrive.

entranceFees.description: 7-day pass for Yellowstone National Park. Snowmobile entry limited to guided tours or permit holders.
entranceFees.title: Yellowstone (motorcycle or snowmobile)

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance to Yellowstone National Park for one year; valid through the month of purchase. Winter use: On a snowmobile, admits the signers and children (residing in the same household under the age of 21). In a snowcoach or shuttle, it admits the signers and up to three additional persons (16 and older) for a total of four people.
entrancePasses.title: Yellowstone National Park Annual Pass

images.altText: Photo of bison in Lamar Valley
images.title: Bison in Lamar Valley
images.caption: Bison in Lamar Valley

example.name: Yellowstone

operatingHours.name: All Park Hours
operatingHours.description: Yellowstone is open daily, year-round, although activities and services are limited at night and certain times of year. The park has five entrance stations, but not all entrance stations are open year-round. Make sure to carefully read about access at each station at different times of year. And remember, all dates are weather dependent!  Please note that camping is possible only in designated campgrounds.

operatingHours.name: West Entrance
operatingHours.description: Adjacent to the town of West Yellowstone, MT, the West Entrance is usually open (weather dependent) to wheeled vehicles from the third Friday in April through early November, and to tracked-oversnow (snowmobiles and snowcoaches) vehicles from December 15 to March 15.

example.weatherInfo: Yellowstone's weather can vary quite a bit, even in a single day. In the summer, daytime highs can exceed 70F (25C), only to drop 20 or more degrees when a thunderstorm rolls through. It can snow during any month of the year, and winter lows frequently drop below zero, especially at night. Bring a range of clothing options, including a warm jacket and rain gear, even in the summer.

bodyText.title: Body Text
bodyText.example: Though trained as an actress, Pauline Cushman-Fryer's legacy is her service as a spy for the Union during the Civil War. During a stage performance in Louisville, Kentucky, Cushman-Fryer boldly proposed a toast to Jefferson Davis at the behest of Union officers (in the script, the toast was supposed to go to President Lincoln).

listingDescription.title: Listing Description
listingDescription.example: Actress and Civil War spy, Pauline Cushman-Fryer narrowly escaped execution for her service to the Union cause. Undercover in Tennessee she performed an illness to escape hanging. She is buried in the Officer's section of the San Francisco National Cemetery at the Presidio.

data.value: The only working sled dog kennels in the National Park System
data.name: Significance:

example.audioDescription: In the center is the historic kennels building. It is a brown, wooden, two story building. There are two entrances to the building on the front side. The door to the west has the words Sled Room above it. On the western side of the building is the dog yard where about 30 dogs live. A gravel path leads visitors through the yard. To the north side are two rows of dog houses made out of wood logs. Each dog is tethered to their housing area. On the south side of the dog yard is a row of pens made of wire fencing. There is one dog in each pen and they also each have a log dog house. The dogs can be on their log house, in it, or next to it. The dogs are all different colors, mixes of brown, white, black, and gray. On the eastern side of the kennels building are the stands for the sled dog demonstration. Steps lead up to different rows where people can stand and watch the presentation. In the first row of most of the sections there is bench seating. In the demonstration area, there is a rectangular gravel pit with a pair of antlers, pile of wood, and sound equipment to be used as props in the demonstration.
example.listingDescription: Explore the only working sled dog kennels in the National Park System.
example.title: Sled Dog Kennels
example.bodyText: Located about 3 miles inside the park at Park Headquarters, the sled dog kennels are open year-round for visitors to meet some of the 30 dogs who live and work in Denali.  During the summer, sled dog demonstrations are offered daily. Rangers and dogs work together to demonstrate a traditional Alaskan mode of travel. These unique, 30 minute programs include an opportunity to tour the park kennels and visit Denali's Alaskan huskies. Demonstrations are given three times daily in peak season (June 1 through September 1), at 10 am, 2 pm and 4 pm. Ask at the visitor center for demonstration times outside of peak season (May and September).  In winter, the dogs and rangers are frequently busy working deep in the park rather than at the kennels, so you may wish to inquire at the visitor center before coming to see if the dogs are around.  Welcoming visitors to the dog yard, the historic kennels building is the oldest building in the park that is still used for its original purpose. Step inside the Sled Room to learn about the history of mushing in Alaska and in the park. Sled dogs and rangers continue to work together to protect the wilderness of the park as they have since the 1920s.

locationDescription.title: Location Description
locationDescription.example: The trail begins at Warm Creek picnic area and ends in Silver Gate, Montana.

longDescription.title: Long Description
longDescription.example: The Bannock Ski Trail is a 2 mile (3.2 km) easy ski that follows the old road bed that once used to supply the mining town of Cooke City, Montana. Begin at Warm Creek picnic area, one mile west of the Northeast Entrance. This trail takes its name from the Bannock band of the Shoshone, who used this route to reach the buffalo grounds of the Great Plains. After crossing Soda Butte Creek, the terrain is mostly flat and the trail traverses open meadows and mixed conifer forests. You will reach the North Absaroka Wilderness approximately one mile (1.6 km) from the trailhead. At two miles (3.2 km) you come to Silver Gate, Montana. From here the road bed is used as a snowmobile route and is good skiing to Cooke City, 3 miles (4.8 km) to the east.

durationDescription.title: Duration Description
durationDescription.example: The duration will vary depending on fitness level, snow conditions, and length of time spent along the trail.

shortDescription.title: Short Description
shortDescription.example: The Bannock Ski Trail is a 2 mile (3.2 km) easy ski that follows the old road bed that once used to supply the mining town of Cooke City, Montana.

example.accessibilityInformation: This skier-tracked easy trail follows a fairly flat old road after crossing a narrow bridge over Soda Butte Creek at the trailhead. The trail elevation gain/loss is 132 feet. Service dogs allowed with backcountry access permit.
example.petsDescription: Qualified service animals are welcome throughout the park and in all park facilities. However, they must be leashed and under your control at all times. This trail requires a backcountry access pass for service animals.

example.title: Blank
example.description: Museum contains a reproduction 3-pounder cannon, other weapons of the Revolutionary War period, and exhibits. "Cowpens: A Battle Remembered" is an 18-minute video shown hourly in the museum.  Fiber-optic Map illustrates the Southern Campaign of the American Revolution and the battle tactics employed by Daniel Morgan at Cowpens. (13 minutes) Sales Outlet operated by Eastern National offers books, postcards, and theme-related souvenirs.
example.directionsInfo: Cowpens National Battlefield is 3 miles west of Chesnee, 10 miles east of Gaffney, and 17 miles south of Spartanburg on SC Hwy 11. For more detailed information, please visit our webpage at http://www.nps.gov/cowp/planyourvisit/directions.htm.
example.name: Cowpens National Battlefield

example.directionsInfo: Upon arriving in Denali, travel 1.5 miles down the road until you see signs for the Denali Visitor Center.
